FACILITY DESCRIPTION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

Eastman is a chemical company which manufactures acetic acid and plasticizers at its TCO Plant.  It also maintains terminal operations for methanol, 2-ethylhexanol, and triethyl phosphate at its facility.

The TCO Plant covers approximately 290 acres within the Texas City Industrial Complex, and is located at 201 Bay Street South in Texas City, Texas, Galveston County.   It has marine facilities for receiving ships and barges, facilities for delivery and shipment of chemicals by rail and truck, and a network of pipelines supplying necessary feedstocks.

There are 128 Eastman employees at the TCO Plant, and the hourly employees are represented by the Texas City, Texas Metal Trades Council, AFL-CIO.  There may be approximately 300 total workers in the plant at any one time during labor-intensive activities such as turnarounds. 

Eastman presently does not store or handle any flammable substances identified by the RMP regulation.  It does, however, store and handle one toxic chemical (chlorine) in a quantity greater than the threshold quantity specified by the RMP regulation.  Chlorine is used for water treatment at Eastman and is delivered by a specially-equipped truck designed to transport one-ton chlorine containers.  Two (2) one-ton containers may be in use at the TCO Plant at any one time for the purification of water.

Executive Summary


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Safety is Eastman Chemical's (Eastman) highest priority.  Prevention of workplace incidents, injuries, and illnesses is vital for the well-being of people in and around our sites and for the success of Eastman.  At the Texas City Operations site (TCO Plant), we believe all incidents, injuries and illnesses are preventable, and we place strong emphasis on six basic safety expectations which are applicable both on and off the job: 

1.)	Follow procedures and safety rules
2.)	Take time to do the job safely
3.)	Identify and eliminate hazards
4.)	Watch out for co-workers
5.)	Report all job-related injuries or illnesses
6.)	Use appropriate personal protective equipment

Eastman also believes adherence to the following nine principles are vital to maintaining a safe workplace:

Management Leadership & Accountability - Each Manager establishes clear safety expectations and goals, provides resources, establishes processes, and monitors overall progress.  

Employee Involvement - Each employee is committed to working safely and to protecting the safety of others.  Employees participate fully in all elements of the safety program.

Regulatory Compliance - Compliance with applicable laws and regulations is an integral part of Eastman's safety program.  

Inclusive Scope - Prevention of workplace incidents, injuries, and illnesses for employees, contractors, visitors, suppliers, and customers is our safety objective.  Providing the skills and attitude to work safely off the job is our expanded goal.

Incident Prevention - Work-related incidents are prevented through several layers of protection, including safe design, safe work practices, safe behaviors, and the use of appropriate engineering, operating, and administrative controls.

ystem, Eastman manages changes to its process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) program and EPA's Risk Management Program.  This system helps prevent or minimize the potential consequences associated with a catastrophic release of highly hazardous chemicals at the TCO Plant.

Eastman's MOC system includes the conducting of Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs) for new facilities and for modified facilities in accordance with the PSM and RMP regulations.  These PSSRs are conducted to verify appropriate safety information has been updated, required reviews have been performed, and necessary training has been completed.

An important part of Eastman's accidental release prevention program is its Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) program.  A PHA is a study which is conducted by a multi-discipline team of employees to determine the ways in which a chemical process may deviate from the design intent.  The PHA Team consists of well-trained personnel knowledgeable in the technology and operations of the particular unit or process under study.  The PHA Teams make recommendations concerning any issues which they feel warrant some follow-up discussion or action, and Management assigns responsibility to each recommendation.  These recommendations are then tracked to completion based on documented responses from the responsible individuals.  A PHA is revalidated at least every five years to ensure it is consistent with the current process.  The chlorine system has had five PHAs conducted on it so far, and all recommendations resulting from these PHAs have been addressed.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Since Eastman's initial RMP submittal in June 1999, there have been no accidental releases of RMP regulated chemicals in accordance with the reporting requirements outlined in 40 CFR Part 68.42. 


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Eastman maintains an on-site Emergency Response Team and provides them with equipment, training, and procedures to ensure prompt mitigation actions are taken during incidents, as well as to facilitate rapid communications with the City of Texas City to warn officials of any potential impact on the neighboring community.  Eastman also has procedures to address inclement weather which may affect process operations at the TCO Plant, such as a hurricane or freezing temperatures.

The TCO Plant has an Emergency Response Plan which establishes responsibilities and requirements for responding to emergencies that might occur at the site.  Each manufacturing department also has emergency operating procedures for the safe operation and/or shutdown of plant operations during an emergency.  Together, and with the use of an Incident Command System (ICS) modeled after the National Incident Management System (NIMS) framework, Eastman provides a systematic and proactive approach to respond to incidents in a manner which reduces injuries, community impact, property damage, and harm to the environment.

The Incident Command System is the organization of employees who responds to an emergency in various support roles, such as the Incident Commander, Officers, firefighters, medical responders, and Emergency Communications Coordinator.  

Eastman also is a member of the Texas City Industrial Mutual Aid System (IMAS), which coordinates mutual response activities between the local industrial community and the City of Texas City.  

The Emergency Communications Coordinator supports the Incident Commander (IC) by coordinating notifications and communications between the IC, Management, and internal and ext

ernal resources (e.g. off-hours personnel, the City of Texas City, and/or IMAS). 

All members of the Emergency Response Team are highly trained to meet the requirements of the roles they fill, and receive training continually throughout the year.  Firefighters receive Live Industrial Rescue and Firefighting training from Texas A&M, HAZWOPER Technician Level training, and training on confined space rescues.  Officers receive additional training.  

Members of the Eastman Medical and Response Team have been trained extensively in the assessment and treatment of injuries and illnesses.  Many are licensed as an Emergency Medical Technician (EMT).

Eastman conducts numerous drills each year on the elements of its emergency response plan to ensure everyone understands his or her role and responsibilities.  Such drills include confined space rescue, fire truck exercises, medical scenarios, tabletop scenarios, and personal protective equipment inspection and donning exercises.  One drill addresses a scenario of chlorine being released from a one-ton chlorine container.  A major drill is also conducted with the other members of the IMAS organization.

Following each drill, members of the Emergency Response Team and other personnel perform a critique to evaluate the effectiveness of the emergency response plan and activities associated with it.  Critiques also are performed after actual incidents.

Members of the Emergency Response Team and the Health, Safety, Environmental, and Security (HSES) Department are responsible for the maintenance of equipment and fire protection systems used to respond to a fire or chemical release.  This includes vehicles, fixed fire protection systems, portable fire protection systems, and personal protective equipment.

The employee alarm system is described in the Emergency Response Plan, and it is also described in the Eastman Texas City Site-Specific training which all Eastman employees and Contractors must receive annually.  D
